content:
“Love & Resistance”, a new exhibition at New York Public Library, marks 50 years since a routine police raid ignited the modern gay-rights movement

ON JUNE 28th 1969 a routine raid on the stonewall Inn did not go to plan. While the police waited outside the gay bar for their wagons, a crowd began to form. Officers became flustered and rough, and when one struck a female patron with a baton the throng became agitated. Pennies, bottles and stones began to fly; chants filled the streets of Greenwich Village. A riot erupted—one that would continue on the streets around stonewall for five days, but that would also galvanise a much wider movement. America’s LGBTQ citizens stepped out from their underground venues, and into the street. 

“Love & Resistance: Stonewall 50”, a new exhibition at the New York Public Library, reflects on this turning point in history. One section explores the importance of protest, while another examines the role of bars such as Stonewall in giving LGBTQ people a safe place to meet. It makes full use of an extensive collection of art, posters, literature and other ephemera to supplement the work of Kay Tobin Lahusen and Diana Davies, two photojournalists who recorded the growth of America’s modern gay-rights movement. 

Much of the collection on display at the library captures this defiance. Ms Davies’s pictures, spanning the 1960s and ‘70s, are full of emotion and energy, taken at campaigns and scenes of protest. In one image two lesbians squat on the ground, kissing, next to a yellow balloon emblazoned with the word “Gay”; a line of men looks on, bemused. Ms Lahusen photographed protests, too, but her most powerful images are more ordinary, zooming in on the faces of activists as they go about their daily lives. One famous picture from her series on homosexuality and religion, taken in the 1970s, shows two men passionately kissing in front of an Episcopalian church sign. 

White gay men are often presented as the sole drivers of the gay-rights movement, but Mr Baumann and the library have gone to great lengths to showcase the range of activists involved. One part of the exhibition considers the racial diversity of the campaign, drawing attention to leaders and publications that rallied on behalf of minorities; a copy of the “Combahee River Collective Statement”, a founding document of contemporary black feminism, sits alongside Third-world Women’s Gay-zette . Room is also afforded to tell the stories of transgender and Transvestite people. Ms Davies’s photos feature Marsha P. Johnson, a black Stonewall activist today regarded as a transgender pioneer. Volumes of Transvestia  (pictured, above), a journal published in the 1960s, are displayed in a fascinating collection of trans literature. “Transvestites have two balls” quips a headline in another publication, reporting on two drag nights held in New Jersey in the early 1970s. 

But the most moving part of the exhibition is the section simply titled “Love”. Among the images are close-ups of couples in tender embraces, hand-in-hand on marches or simply reading the newspaper. One photo taken by Ms Lahusen shows Barbara Gittings, her life-long partner and fellow activist, poking her head around a shower curtain, mid-wash, with a playful smile. It is sweet in its ordinariness, and crystallises the impetus behind the gay-rights movement: it was a quest to lead a normal life on the same terms as everyone else.

“Love & Resistance: Stonewall 50” runs until July 14th at the New York Public Library’s Stephen A. Schwarzman Building

Title: Looking back on the Stonewall riots and their aftermath

paperStatistics.title: Looking back on the Stonewall riots and their aftermath
paperStatistics.desc: “Love & Resistance”, a new exhibition at New York Public Library, marks 50 years since a routine police raid ignited the modern gay-rights movement
